author: Alblas
title: “Meat” Me in the Middle: The Potential of a Social Norm Feedback Intervention in the Context of Meat Consumption – A Conceptual Replication
brief_description: message showing them “The results of last week show that the average meat consumption of Dutch residents was: 1.32 times per day.” In addition, participants in the descriptive norm only conditions received descriptive norm feedback: “Based on your answers, it appears that your meat consumption is above-/below- average compared to the average Dutch resident.” (but we didn't incldue that condition because the treatment is modified based on post-treatment data)
outcome: self-reported MAP consumption: "During the three weeks of data collection, participants were asked to report their meat consumption on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays."
notes: RCT issue (post-radomization bias): what treatment people get depends on their behaviors. Interesting study. there's a second treatment condition we didn't include because of post-treatment non-randomness. Some people in the injunctive norm get a frowny face if they are eating above average meat and a smiley face if they are doing better than average. But that's based on baseline covariate data gathered in the data collection process, so effectively there are *two* treatments, one with a positive mersage and one with a negative, but the negative or positive message isn't randomly assigned. Final note: the overall effect size for that condition was 0.01.

author: Alblas
title: “Meat” Me in the Middle: The Potential of a Social Norm Feedback Intervention in the Context of Meat Consumption – A Conceptual Replication
brief_description: you get a message about whether your meat consumption is above or below average for the population along witha. frowny face if you are above or a smiley face if you are below
outcome: self-reported MAP consumption: "During the three weeks of data collection, participants were asked to report their meat consumption on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays."
notes: RCT issue (post-RCT issue bias): what treatment people get depends on their behaviors. Interesting study. there's a second treatment condition we didn't include because of post-treatment non-randomness. Some people in the injunctive norm get a frowny face if they are eating above average meat and a smiley face if they are doing better than average. But that's based on baseline covariate data gathered in the data collection process, so effectively there are *two* treatments, one with a positive mersage and one with a negative, but the negative or positive message isn't randomly assigned. Final note: the overall effect size for that condition was 0.01.

author: Beresford
title: Low-fat dietary pattern and risk of colorectal cancer: the Women’s Health Initiative Randomized Controlled Dietary Modification Trial
brief_description: intensive behavioral modification pro- gram, using 18 group sessions in the first year and quarterly sessions there- after, led by specially trained and cer- tified nutritionists.
outcome: Red meat, medium servings/d
notes: encourages substitution to fish. This is a tough call, because it does show overall reductions (I calculated the effects before I understood that) but looking at the supplementary materials on the trial (https://sp.whi.org/researchers/studydoc/WHI%20and%20ES1%20Manual%20of%20Operations/1993-2005%20WHI%20CT%20and%20OS/Vol%202,%2006%20-%20Dietary%20Modification%20(DM).pdf), we see that part of the counseling was "Identify ways to increase fish consumption."

author: Better Food Foundation
title: Serving up Plants by Default
brief_description: at three university cafeterias,
outcome: proportion of vegan meals sold
notes: other: not enough information to calculate the *net* effect size. as far as I can see, we're missing data on effects at the cafeteria overall, and a lot of people switched to other food stations). We can take the effect of treatment on the particular stations as a given and that's perhaps a biased estimate of the effect overall. The authors present an uncertainty bound where we assume that the decline in meals chosen on default days is entirely driven by people who go elsewhere and then choose meat., and then we get an effect of a relative reduction of  21.6%. But that's a lot of guesswork. A reader might find this problem less of a concern and take their estimate at face value, and if so, it's a very promsing result.

author: Celis-Morales
title: Effect of personalized nutrition on health-related behaviour change: evidence from the Food4Me European randomized controlled trial
brief_description: Personalized Nutrition (PN) program based on individual dietary intake data alone encouraging less intake of red meat and salt and saturated fat
outcome: grams of red meat
country: Ireland, The Netherlands, Spain, Greece, the UK, Poland, and Germany
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish): "Oily fish is full of essential omega-3 fatty acids - try to have 1 portion of oily fish per week" in the supplementary materials)

author: Celis-Morales
title: Effect of personalized nutrition on health-related behaviour change: evidence from the Food4Me European randomized controlled trial
brief_description: Personalized Nutrition (PN) program based on individual dietary intake and phenotypic data encouraging less intake of red meat and salt and saturated fat
outcome: grams of red meat
country: Ireland, The Netherlands, Spain, Greece, the UK, Poland, and Germany
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish): "Oily fish is full of essential omega-3 fatty acids - try to have 1 portion of oily fish per week" in the supplementary materials)

author: Celis-Morales
title: Effect of personalized nutrition on health-related behaviour change: evidence from the Food4Me European randomized controlled trial
brief_description: Personalized Nutrition (PN) program based on personalized dietary advice based on individual dietary intake and phenotypic and genotypic data encouraging less intake of red meat and salt and saturated fat
outcome: grams of red meat
country: Ireland, The Netherlands, Spain, Greece, the UK, Poland, and Germany
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish): "Oily fish is full of essential omega-3 fatty acids - try to have 1 portion of oily fish per week" in the supplementary materials)

author: Dannenberg
title: The effects of observability and an information nudge on food choice
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: survey in which university students are told that 60% of students in a survey are vegetarian/vegan and then 20% are given a private opportunity to select a voucher for a meal with meat or not
outcome: does the meal have meat or not
notes: no delay, but a strong study and shows clear backlash effects to being observed. Maybe annoyance with the blatantness of the experimental procedure? LIke the *clear* attempt to manipulate people into eating less meat (nudging them about the environmental consequences of meat and then telling them "your choice will be public.") By contrast,the nudge alone seems to produce reasonable effects. That, or there's just random variation and if you average all the treatment groups you get about the baseline effect. Noting that we found a 2023 preprint version of this paper but are taking stats from the published Food Policy article.

author: Dannenberg
title: The effects of observability and an information nudge on food choice
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: survey in which university students are told that 10% of students in a survey are vegetarian/vegan and then 20% are given an opportunity to select a voucher for a meal with meat or not but the results are public
outcome: does the meal have meat or not
notes: no delay, but a strong study and shows clear backlash effects to being observed. Maybe annoyance with the blatantness of the experimental procedure? LIke the *clear* attempt to manipulate people into eating less meat (nudging them about the environmental consequences of meat and then telling them "your choice will be public.") By contrast,the nudge alone seems to produce reasonable effects. That, or there's just random variation and if you average all the treatment groups you get about the baseline effect. Noting that we found a 2023 preprint version of this paper but are taking stats from the published Food Policy article.

author: Delichatsios
title: EatSmart: efficacy of a multifaceted preventive nutrition intervention in clinical practice
brief_description: (1) mailed personalized dietary recom- mendations and educational booklets focusing on fruits and vegetables, red m’eat, and dairy foods, tai- lored to patients’baseline intake and stage of readiness to change eating behaviors; (2) verbal endorsement by the primary care provider of the benefits of these rec- ommendations; and (3) two motivational counseling sessions with telephone counselors to set dietary goals.
outcome: weekly servings of red and/or processed meat
outcome_category: servings of red and processed meat per week
notes: underpowered (6 clusters). The SD is something back of the envelope based on the confidence intervals. The overall effect is an "Intent-to treat analysis adjusted for age, sex, race, and baseline value of the food intake."

author: Epperson
title: Information Avoidance and Moral Behavior: Experimental Evidence from Food Choices
brief_description: 360° video about the living conditions of pigs in intensive farming via a virtual reality (VR) headset combined with willingness to pay aspect (to avoid the film)
outcome: food purchases at Canteen
notes: RCT issue (not randomized): subjects have some ability to select into and out of treatment with willingness to pay variance. But treatment is still plausibly exogenous because of the random variation of the actual price point so it's borderline

author: Frie
title: Effectiveness of an Online Programme to Tackle Individual’s Meat Intake through SElf‑regulation (OPTIMISE): A randomised controlled trial
brief_description: Online Programme to Tackle Individual Meat Intake through SElf-regulation where participants choose strategies to cut back on meat consumption and then get daily reminders to implement those strategies and comparisons to their initial meat consumption
outcome: meat frequency questionnaire
notes: RCT issue (horse race design):  control "participants were asked to try to reduce their meat consumption during the following eight weeks with no further guidance")

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: putting vegetarian meals first (VegFirst) in a cafeteria setting with the non-veg option 181 cm behind in college B
outcome: proportion of vegetarian meals sold
notes: RCT issue (not randomized): Arguably the 'weekly' alteration is in the right ballpark but it's not really random. For the purposes of this robustness check we're looking at all the weekly alteration interventions, each as its own data point

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: putting vegetarian meals first (VegFirst) in a cafeteria setting with the non-veg option 85 cm behind in college A
outcome: proportion of vegetarian meals sold
notes: RCT issue (not randomized). Arguably the 'weekly' alteration is in the right ballpark but it's not really random. For the purposes of this robustness check we're looking at all the weekly alteration interventions, each as its own data point

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: putting vegetarian meals first (VegFirst) in a cafeteria setting with the non-veg option 85 cm behind in college B
outcome: proportion of vegetarian meals sold
notes: RCT issue (not randomized): Arguably the 'weekly' alteration is in the right ballpark but it's not really random. For the purposes of this robustness check we're looking at all the weekly alteration interventions, each as its own data point

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "“Did you know? On average, 44% of our canteen customers chose a vegan or vegetarian main dish during the last winter term."
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "Did you know? On average, 56% of our canteen customers chose a main dish containing meat or fish during the last winter term."
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "What do you think was the proportion of vegan or vegetarian main dishes sold in our canteen last winter term? ___% of the main dishes sold during the last winter term were vegan or vegetarian.”
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "What do you think was the proportion of meat and fish main dishes sold in our canteen last winter term? ___% of the main dishes sold during the last winter term contained meat, sausage or fish."
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Hansen
title: Nudging healthy and sustainable food choices: three randomized controlled field experiments using a vegetarian lunch-default as a normative signal
brief_description: three conference registrations where participants sign up for a meal; the default is vegetarian or not
outcome: does the meal have meat or not
notes: no delay. It's actually a really interesting datapoint for talking about how traditional psych/behavioral science studies and these kinds of actual real world interventions can be hard to integrate. This one does have an effect, and it does have policy-relevant implications, as does Gravert 2019. It just doesn't show enduring effects (people might have a meat dish the next day to compensate or something).

author: Hansen
title: Nudging healthy and sustainable food choices: three randomized controlled field experiments using a vegetarian lunch-default as a normative signal

author: Johansen
title: Changes in food habits and motivation for healthy eating among Pakistani women living in Norway: results from the InnvaDiab-DEPLAN study
brief_description: six sessions, each about 2 hours, on nutrition for Pakistani women living in Oslo
outcome: food frequency questionnaire (intake of red meats/week)
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish). a lot of the effect size is guesswork, I combined the chicken, red meat, and fish categories into one, and then estimated SD from a combination fo the p values (assuming from a t-test). But I think it's probably in the right ballpark

author: Kaiser
title: Financial rewards for long-term environmental protection
brief_description: free vegetarian meals for a week (outcomes measured a week after that) at a German university cafeteria
outcome: self-reported proportion of vegetarian meals eaten
notes: RCT issue (procedural issue): p. 7 where they weren't sure how to account for 32 participants, which is about 10%, and the treatment groups are lopsided.

author: Lentz
title: Meat consumption and potential reduction for environmental and public health benefits
brief_description: film sessions held in rented rooms within the School of Geography at the University of Otago where participants watched one of three videos advocating for eating less meat or a control video about Jim Carcey's performance as Andy Kaufman in 'Man on the Moon'
outcome: proportion saying they reduced their meat intake
notes: underpowered (about 21-22 subjects per arm). But actually a very nice design and of relevance to other forthcoming documentary studies

author: Lentz
title: Meat consumption and potential reduction for environmental and public health benefits
brief_description: film sessions held in rented rooms within the School of Geography at the University of Otago where participants watched one of three videos advocating for eating less meat or a control video about Jim Carcey's performance as Andy Kaufman in 'Man on the Moon'
outcome: proportion saying they reduced their meat intake
notes: underpowered (about 21-22 subjects per arm). But actually a very nice design and of relevance to other forthcoming documentary studies

author: Lentz
title: Meat consumption and potential reduction for environmental and public health benefits
brief_description: film sessions held in rented rooms within the School of Geography at the University of Otago where participants watched one of three videos advocating for eating less meat or a control video about Jim Carcey's performance as Andy Kaufman in 'Man on the Moon'
outcome: proportion saying they reduced their meat intake
notes: underpowered (about 21-22 subjects per arm). But actually a very nice design and of relevance to other forthcoming documentary studies

author: Loy
title: Supporting Sustainable Food Consumption: Mental Contrasting with Implementation Intentions (MCII) Aligns Intentions and Behavior
brief_description: mental contrasting with implementation intentions (MCII) wherepeople identify and imagine a desired future andcurrent obstacles standing in its way, then  address the obstacles with if-then plans specifying when, where, and how to act differently.
outcome: food diary (meat reduction in grams per day)
notes: RCT issue (horse race design): Control group receives information ("All participants read a text providing information about meat consumption...It not only addressed environmental consequences of meat consumption but also other arguments for reduced consumption...These further arguments referred to ethical, health, and social/political aspects of meat consumption including references to scientific publications") where treatment group also receives "mental contrasting with implementation intentions (MCII)" intervention. There's a third condition that was collected and presented in the first author's thesis but it will compare to the same control group

author: Matthews
title: Longitudinal effect of 20-year infancy-onset dietary intervention on food consumption and nutrient intake: the randomized controlled STRIP study
intervention_condition: Special Turku Coronary Risk Factor Intervention Project (STRIP)
brief_description: 30-minute individualized dietary counseling and nutrition education sessions led by a nutritionist...individualized in that the dietary counseling was based on the child’s diet as assessedthrough food records, and they addressed specific dietary questions and concerns of the families.
outcome: four day dietary recall
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish). again the SD numbers are a bit of a guess

author: Piazza
title: Monitoring a meat-free pledge with smartphones: An experimental study
brief_description: recruited to take a pledge to do your best to stop eating meat for a month
outcome: self-reported meat consumption
notes: RCT issue (horse race design): (all participants received information about going meat free). A bit tricky to get a handle on the effect sizesbut the difference in the treatment group is B =0.01 and the difference in the control gruop is B = -0.01 so we're calling it an unspecified null of 0.01. The Ns are also ab it of a guess beacuse we don't know how many people were in each group (At all sites, the briefing sessions, which lasted approximately 30–40 min, were run with 2–8 participants to reduce the number of total sessions required...random assignment was applied to sessions")

author: Reinders
title: Menu-engineering in restaurants - adapting portion sizes on plates to enhance vegetable consumption: a real-life experiment
brief_description: the vegetable portion sizes on the plates of main dishes were doubled (150 g of vegetables instead of 75 g) and the portion sizes of meat on the plates were reduced by an average of 12.5%.
outcome: grams of meat eaten
notes: underpowered (3 clusters) but still a nice study, worth summarising

author: Sparkman
title: Dynamic Norms Promote Sustainable Behavior, Even if It Is Counternormative
brief_description: a survey which presents information about people who try to limit their meat consumption (static)
outcome: whether their meal has meat or not
notes: no delay. Takes places over multiple days but there is zero delay between treatment and any indiivdual meal choice. We have some other studies where a person is typically going to choose right away but there is at least some theoretical possibility that someone encounters the treatment on multiple days and therefore gets attenuated Stanford students.  edge case for place-based but I'm saying yes because "Café patrons waiting in line for lunch completed a survey- based intervention". Also, provides materials but not prergistration or open data: https://osf.io/yxf2t

author: Sparkman
title: Dynamic Norms Promote Sustainable Behavior, Even if It Is Counternormative
brief_description: a survey which presents information about people who are *changing* their behavior to  to limit their meat consumption (dynamic)
outcome: whether their meal has meat or not
notes: no delay. Takes places over multiple days but there is zero delay between treatment and any indiivdual meal choice. We have some other studies where a person is typically going to choose right away but there is at least some theoretical possibility that someone encounters the treatment on multiple days and therefore gets attenuated Stanford students.  edge case for place-based but I'm saying yes because "Café patrons waiting in line for lunch completed a survey- based intervention". Also, provides materials but not prergistration or open data: https://osf.io/yxf2t
